Title: Direct projections from the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus of the amygdala to the principal part of the cortical masticatory area in the macaque monkey
Abstract: Direct projections from the amygdala to the cortical masticatory area were found in the macaque monkey. Under the guidance of intracortical microstimulation, retrograde tracers were injected into multiple jaw movement-related regions of the frontal lobe. The cortical masticatory area, especially its principal part, stimulation of which elicited rhythmic jaw movement, was the only site of injection that produced neuronal labeling in the amygdala. The cells of origin of such projections were localized in the medial aspect of the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus through its rostral level. No labeled neurons were observed in the amygdala after tracer injection into any other cortical jaw movement-related region. The present results suggest that the amygdaloid input to the cortical masticatory area may exert some modulatory influence on the generation of masticatory rhythm.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation:
"Many lines of evidence clearly indicate that multiple jaw movement-related regions reside in the primate motor cortex [4-7, 9-11, 13, 16, 18-20, 23, 24]. Among these regions, included are orofacial representations of the primary motor cortex (MI) and the supplementary motor area (SMA) [4, 6, 7, 9-11, 13, 16, 18-20, 23, 24].
According to Huang et al. [5], the CMA is composed of two distinct regions: the principal part (CMAp) that is located in the precentral gyrus anterolateral to the MI orofacial representation and the deep part (CMAd) that is located in the inner face of the frontal operculum." (p. 220)
"To identify the jaw movement-related regions of the frontal lobe, intracortical microstimulation (ICMS) was performed...
Electrolytical microlesions (anodal direct currents of 10-15 microA, 20-30s) were placed to verify the exact locations of electrode penetration.
After ICMS mapping, a single or two points were selected for injection of wheat germ agglutinin conjugated-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) or biotinylated dextrane amine (BDA).
...In three of the five monkeys, paired injections of WGA-HRP and BDA were made into two of the MI, SMA, CMAp and CMAd." (p. 221)
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Comments: Although it was only for CMAp clearly shown (figures 1-2) that it was delineated, the textual description clarify that the other motor areas were also delineated.

@Methods.Comments:
Citation: "In three of the five monkeys, paired injections of WGA-HRP and BDA were made into two of the MI, SMA, CMAp and CMAd." (p. 221)
This citation shows that it was not clearly stated how often the different motor were affected by the injection.

@Injections.Citation:
"In three of the five monkeys, paired injections of WGA-HRP and BDA were made into two of the MI, SMA, CMAp and CMAd." (p. 221)
"We injected WGA-HRP into the CMAp in two monkeys and confirmed by histological eyamination that the sites of WGA-HRP injection were neatly localized therein (Figs. 1 and 2A). In the same or different monkeys, WGA-HRP or BDA was similarly injected into the orofacial regons of the MI and SMA, including those related to single jaw movement and, also, into a rhythmic jaw movement-related region in the inner face of the frontal operculum, corresponding probably to the CMAd." (p. 222)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "We also observed the amygdala in the case of WGA-HRP or BDA injection into the orofacial regions of the MI and SMA and into CMAd. However, neither MI nor SMA injection did produce neuronal labeling in any amygdaloid nucleus. Very few, if any, neurons were labeled in the Bmc after BDA injection into CMAd," (p. 222)

publication.abstract: Direct projections from the amygdala to the cortical masticatory area were found in the macaque monkey. The present results suggest that the amygdaloid input to the cortical masticatory area may exert some modulatory influence on the generation of masticatory rhythm.
